11:09 am
PM

Citi's political strategist

BE

Yeah, sure. Personally, I'm very happy not to have opinions this morning.

BE

Tina can have them instead.

11:09 am
PM

Paris Attacks Deadliest since World War II: Friday night's horrific synchronised
terrorist attacks in Paris mark the deadliest in the city since World War II. The
strikes, which have killed over 129 people and prompted the temporary closure of
the French border, come 10 months after the Charlie Hebdo attack, which was
followed by the imposition of what are regarded as some of the strictest security and
surveillance measures in Europe.
This Time It's Different. The Charlie Hebdo attack prompted widespread solidarity,
yet little broader change in European or US strategy toward countering terrorism or
addressing the conflict in the Middle East. We think this time is different, and signals
that IS has changed its strategy. With this in mind, we have upgraded the risk of
terrorist attacks not only in the Middle East but also in the West, as well as the
likelihood of increased international military intervention in IS strongholds in Syria,
Iraq and Libya.

PM

Sinai, Beirut and Paris: The Paris attacks, themselves marking a change in trend
in their synchronised nature, came days after the worst suicide bombing in Beirut
since the civil conflict ended in 1990, and two weeks after the downing of a Russian
passenger airliner over Sinai. All attacks have been claimed by IS (though not
conclusively confirmed), all would have required significant planning, and possibly
central coordination. Such a series of successful attacks on targets aligned with
countries at war with IS in Syria suggests a new front in the conflict, with IS moving
beyond fighting in Syria and Iraq to extending the theatre of war beyond its
"caliphate"

PM

Global Implications: The aftermath of the November 13 Paris attacks may not in
itself prompt extensive market-based volatility, not least given the tendency of
financial markets to treat such developments as idiosyncratic and the unfortunate
reality of a world where large-scale carnage has become an almost daily, if
sickening, development. Nevertheless, it will have a range of security and political
implications, including serving as a catalyst for other nations to join the US, France
and Russia in launching air strikes against IS positions. We expect the UK
government to be among the first to resume consideration of participating in
attacking IS, amidst fears that doing so risks greater exposure to terrorism in Britain.
It will also force questions about a renewed strategy to go beyond what US
President Obama described as a plan to "degrade IS", which now holds significant
territory in its self-declared "caliphate", and the wisdom of the 2013 decision to forgo
air strikes in Syria when IS was first making inroads. Diplomatic efforts to produce a
political settlement to the Syria conflict will likely also see increased vigour, though
the distance between Moscow and Tehran, which continue to support Syrian
president Assad, and other partners must be bridged to achieve a breakthrough.

11:10 am
PM

More focus on cooperating with Russia and Iran is also likely, but undermined by
inconsistencies in regional foreign policy.

PM

Refugee Crisis Efforts in Europe Likely to Suffer; More Pressure to Restrict
Freedom of Movement: Although full details have yet to emerge, reports that one
of the attackers was a Syrian national who had applied for asylum in Serbia before
travelling to France will intensify opposition to efforts at burden-sharing with regard
to resettling refugees across the EU, a policy that German Chancellor Merkel is
most closely associated with, and bears the greatest political risks of. Although
senior EU officials such as Jean-Claude Juncker have issued calls to refrain from
linking the Paris attacks with policy responses to the refugee crisis, anti-immigration
politicians from Central Europe to the Netherlands are already doing so,
undermining already fraying cooperation. The risks of Brexit, Merkel-exit and likely
greater support for right-wing and anti-immigration political parties in Europe – who
even prior to the Paris attacks have been ascending – have increased. Heightened
calls to restrict freedom of movement, whether by building physical fences,
tightened security measures, "temporary" border closures and the reinstatement of
border controls, is highly likely, contributing to a growing backlash against a key
element of globalisation.

PM

French Regional Elections December 6/13 in Focus: Terrorist attacks can have
concrete political implications if they occur near an election, as was the case in
Spain following the 2004 Madrid bombings. The anti-immigrant and eurosceptic
National Front has been doing well in a number of regional contests, and could
manage to secure two key regions, one of its longstanding goals. Although we
expect that fears over immigration and security could well increase support for the
FN, even boosting the potential that Marine Le Pen is a candidate in the second
round of the French presidential elections in 2017, we maintain our view that she is
extremely unlikely to become president.

11:13 am
BE

And, on defence ....

BE

Here's Stifel to talk budgets.

BE

Paris Attacks Likely to Drive Further U.S. Bombing, Missile Attacks on ISIS - In our view, the initial response from
France and the U.S. is likely to be an acceleration of the bombing and missile campaigns that have been ongoing which
could also broaden in scope. We do not view the attacks as a tipping point that would lead the U.S. to announce any
large-scale troop deployments (if this were to occur, investor sentiment towards defense companies would strengthen, in
our view). Raytheon's Tomahawk missile, Lockheed's Hellfire, and Boeing's Joint Direct Attack Munition (JDAM) and
Small Diameter Bomb (SDB) have been the primary munitions used by the U.S. in aerial attacks against ISIS. Unit costs for these range from ~$100k to ~$1m based on DoD budget documents.

11:14 am
BE

Attacks Likely to Bolster Political Support for Defense Spending & to Eliminate Sequestration - While we had
previously viewed political support in the U.S. for defense spending as fairly strong (with neither Republicans nor
Democrats calling for cuts to defense budgets), the attacks in Paris (and claims from ISIS that the attack is the "first of a
storm") are likely to strengthen this support considerably. Congressman Adam Schiff (D-CA, Intelligence Committee) said,
"It will add another sense of urgency to defeating it. (It) will be very hard to do without eliminating its sanctuary. If this
doesn't create in the world a fierce determination to rid ourselves of this scourge, I don't know what will." The attacks are
also likely to result in national security becoming a more important topic going into the 2016 election cycle which could
lead to favorable headlines as candidates likely become more bullish with their rhetoric around defense spending. In
addition to funding levels from the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015 (note here) which called for y/y growth in the base
budget of 6% in FY16 (stronger than expected), we now see more upside potential than downside risk to the 1% increase
budgeted in FY17 and view 2%-3% as more likely. This is likely to translate into solid low to mid single digit revenue
growth for the industry based on the correlation between defense spending and industry sales (Exhibit 2) with some
companies outperforming this due to international sales growth (Raytheon). Importantly, it makes clear to us that 2015 is
the bottom of this cycle for defense industry revenue.

BE

Intelligence, Surveillance, Reconnaissance (ISR) Demand Will Increase - Initial reports (New York Times, The
Guardian, BBC) suggest that French intelligence officials were aware of increasing operational tempo from ISIS
operatives and had viewed attacks within France as increasingly likely prior to Friday. However, despite efforts to increase
surveillance, French intelligence resources were overwhelmed. "We have now become the Islamic State's enemy number
one," said Marc Trevidic, a former French magistrate specializing in counter-terrorism, just prior to Friday's attacks.
Steven Simon, a former Middle East adviser to President Obama, said, "You're going to see several things: tighter border
controls (and) more intensive surveillance in the U.S." In addition to increased demand for ISR (which is unlikely to move
the needle for any defense company in our coverage), the first area likely to see funding accelerated will be related to
border security. All of the large cap defense companies and certain government services firms (covered by our colleague
Bill Loomis) could be in a position to win such work though it will likely be additive to current contracts initially.

BE

Prior Budget Cycles Typically Driven by Troop Deployments, Not Political Sentiment - The last four major
defense budget cycles (Exhibit 1) have been driven by the Korean War (not shown, 1950-1953), the Vietnam War
(1960s), the Reagan Build Up (1980s), and the Global War on Terror (2001-2010). Three of the four, with the exception
being the Reagan Build Up, coincided with a significant increase in deployed troops. In our view, political support in the
U.S. for a re-deployment of troops to the Middle East seems low and the current ISIS threat seems unlikely to require
the type of troop levels that were needed in Iraq and Afghanistan in the mid 2000s. As a result, we would be surprised
to see any significant shift in strategy from President Obama and expect instead to see an acceleration and broadening
of current efforts - an increase in aerial attacks and a possible increase in the number of special ops forces deployed.
We note that if President Obama does re-authorize troop deployments, we view L-3, Orbital ATK, and
AeroVironment as most likely to see a material impact.

11:14 am
BE

Stronger Political Support Likely - We view the most likely outcome from the attacks in Paris to be stronger support
for defense spending and ongoing operations in the Middle East. A recent CNN/ORC poll indicated that "terrorism" is
the most important topic to only 12% of voters (behind the economy - 44% and health care - 20%) - this compares to it
being the most important topic to roughly 55% of voters in 2007. While we view such support as insufficient at this point
in the defense budget cycle to materially increase defense spending, we believe it will strengthen support to end
sequestration (which currently goes back into effect in FY18) and could boost the 1% base budget increase expected
in FY17 and result in FY16 OCO spending being higher than expected. While appropriators have yet to provide detail
as to how the Bipartisan Budget Act funding will be allocated in FY16 between O&M, procurement, R&D, etc..., we
suspect the investment account will see a low to mid single digit increase which should translate into y/y revenue
growth for defense companies in 2016-2017, following ~5 years of declines (Exhibit 2).

BE

........ all of which gives me a rather leaden feeling in my stomach. But anyway .... Here are the charts.

BE

11:26 am
BE

Once again it was the Telegraph running with a bearish tone on the BG/RDS transaction and it was curious to see our comments manifested in a somewhat negative manner. In fact, quite to the contrary, we have been in contact with both companies and sets of advisors since the Qatari sell filings were published and feedback continues to suggest that the reasons behind the transactions were non-deal related. As we concluded in the original comment, “Clearly it is hard to make a positive from the SWF of the World’s biggest LNG producer selling down exposure to NewCo, but there seems to be some reasonable evidence to suggest that this is part of a bigger picture” [other than the deal].

We continue to maintain an ongoing dialogue with a number of core RDS shareholders and struggle to find any signs of dissent ahead of Q1’s Royal Dutch EGM. More of interest therefore remains why certain elements of the press maintain this bearish tone with very little underlying evidence of a groundswell of a problem. Clearly this is a topic we will endeavour to monitor as we head into the closing stages of the deal.

This morning, it is worth noting QCG’s (of which BG is the parent company) statement that it is investing $1.7bn into its natural gas tenements in Wandoan over the next 2 years. Such development capex was always planned in this project, this was in guidance and approvals had already been attained. However, the timing of the announcement interests ahead of Thursday’s ACCC deadline. There has been increasing questioning in the market in the last few days that we might see a delay from ACCC again this week, although Royal Dutch management still insist that any remedies that might be needed are of negligible size when compared to the overall size / rationale of the transaction. The market has broadly got itself comfortable with the concept that Shell would be willing to dispose of its stake in Arrow, which would appear to be the ultimate (and still unlikely) remedy asked for. Although it remains unclear who the buyer of such an asset would be, if indeed the market is happy that Shell would follow this path, threats posed from the Australian regulatory process still appear minimal.

BE

That's what Olivetree is telling clients this morning. Go to them direct for more. They've been all over this one.

BG Group PLC (BG.:LSE): Last: 982.90, up 15.2 (+1.57%), High: 986.10, Low: 959.10, Volume: 1.43m

Lonmin PLC (LMI:LSE): Last: 9.51, down 0.04 (-0.42%), High: 9.94, Low: 9.17, Volume: 1.40m
11:31 am
PM

BE

Hm. Personally, I suspect it's not closer to the TERP because there's the possibility that shareholders will vote against the cash call.

BE

If they do that, what do bondholders do?

11:33 am
PM

(AmInvest -- Dan very much in touch with the company and may or may not be writing further. can't really comment beyond that at the moment.)

BE

Would bondholders really shut it down? There are a 30-odd thousand South Africans who might not welcome that decision.

BE

11:33 am
BE

In the sense that, even if Lonmin does raise the money, it's still a broken company.

BE

So why not vote against it?

BE

Let me cut to some Barclays here.

11:34 am
BE

Analyst is Andrew Byrne, who's been excellent on Lonmin's long and slow demise.

BE

Our high-level review of Lonmin’s business plan (which is more aggressive than market guidance in terms of production, opex and capex) suggests that at spot prices and FX, the company is likely to remain cashflow negative for the foreseeable future and generate US$385mn of cashflow losses. Assuming normal operational challenges and productivity targets not being achieved, we expect this figure to be closer to US$575mn in reality, leaving the company’s production base impaired with sustainable production of less than 500koz.

BE

11:35 am
BE

Lonmin have released a Life of Business Plan (LoBP) within Competent Persons Report (CPR) as part of their rights issue prospectus. During the company’s results presentation it was inferred by management that this business plan had been stress-tested by third parties and was the underlying supporting documentation behind the company’s view that they will be cashflow positive at spot prices. Whilst the LoBP is aggressive in its cost and productivity assumptions in our opinion given historic company and industry performance, ignoring this, we calculate that Lonmin will be cashflow negative on spot prices. We believe this supports our view that Lonmin is likely to remain cashflow negative for the foreseeable, and given our expectation of continued low prices (due to a surplus metal environment) is likely to raise further capital over the next 2-3 years irrespective of management actions unless PGM prices increase materially. We reiterate our Underweight rating.

PM

Sheesh

BE

To my mind, Lonmin's just not investable.

11:36 am
BE

They're basically doing a quasi IPO of an already listed, lossmaking company that's feared to platinum rallying to get it out of jail.

PM

tied to

BE

And they're doing it because the domestic politics mean it's impossible just to close it down.

11:37 am
BE

In summary, no thanks. There are more simple ways to lose money.

undefined
BE

(@markopolo: yeah, fair point.)

11:39 am
BE

(@fjp73: am I mistaken, or has Lonmin's BEE partner already said it's passing on its call option?)

BE

Back to risers, then.

BE

Rolls currently challenging Imperial at the top of the FTSE.

11:40 am
BE

A rally, clearly. Perhaps encouraged by weekend press.

BE

And perhaps encouraged by a Goldman note, which was out on Friday but seems to have been picked up late by the wires.

BE

It's very long, and rather number dense .......

11:42 am
BE

Gist is that there's a lot of caution in Rolls' guidance.

BE

Rolls Royce has guided to a c.£150 mn EBIT headwind from the Small and Medium engine
business in 2016. This business includes: (1) Corporate Jet OE and Aftermarket; (2)
Regional Jet Aftermarket: and (3) V2500 OE and aftermarket. Rolls-Royce initially guided to
a £50 mn headwind in July this year, driven primarily by a weakening in activity levels on
the 50-70 seat size regional aircraft, as well as some weakness in Corporate OE. Since July,
the Corporate OE has deteriorated; we forecast (Exhibit 1) a 13% reduction in delivered thrust
in 2016, equal to a £142 mn sales headwind for Corporate OE. To arrive at an estimate for
corporate OE sales, we take the 2014 disclosed percentage of Civil Aerospace sales that
related to Small and Medium engines (39%), remove the £700 mn of V2500 related sales and
then assume 60% of sales are OE. We assume a 30% EBIT margin on Corporate OE.
In addition, we expect V2500 to be a £22 mn headwind to profits in 2016. Rolls-Royce
currently assembles V2500 engines for the IAE consortium. V2500 sales will fall as the GTF
enter production; we assume that OE volume is taken away from Rolls-Royce before
production by the consortium partners themselves is changed. This therefore implies a
46% cut to Roll-Royce assembly work in 2016, a £22 mn headwind.
Overall, we expect a £65 mn headwind in the Small and Medium engine business in 2016,
lower than the £150 mn guided. This forecast is sensitive to: (1) OE margins on corporate
engine deliveries; and (2) the process for V2500 production cuts.

BE

The downgrade to the outlook for Large engines is driven by an increased number of
parkings of 777 and A340 aircraft powered by the Trent 800 and 500 respectively. Parked
aircraft do not generate any hourly flight payments and hence are a headwind to EBIT; in
addition, there has been a gradual reduction in the number of hours flown for both types of
engine. We calculate that these two factors amount to a £65 mn profit headwind in 2016
under what we see as very cautious assumptions; this still leaves a large degree of
prudence (£35-85 mn) to get to the guided headwind of £100-150 mn.
Why are the aircraft being parked? At the end of October, there were 33 Trent 800
powered 777 aircraft in storage, up from just two aircraft at the beginning of 2014 (Exhibit
2). Of the 33 parked 777s, 32 had been in service in January 2014. The bulk of this increase
is due to two airlines, Transaero and Malaysia, which account for nine and seven of the
parked aircraft, respectively. This is because both airlines have suspended operations as
they go through a period of restructuring. In our forecasts, we assume these aircraft remain
out of service through 2016. Excluding these two airlines, there are 17 aircraft parked,
which represents 4% of the fleet; this is a normal level of parking, in line with the rates for
Trent 700 and 1000.
What impact does this have on Rolls-Royce profits? Parked engines do not generate any
regular flight hour payments and hence do not contribute to EBIT. We believe the
headwinds identified by Rolls-Royce assume that the current level of parked aircraft is
sustained through 2016 and hence there is an incremental negative impact on earnings. In
addition to this, there are a number of wide-body aircraft coming off lease between now
and the end of 2016. If these aircraft are not released into the market then they will also
cease to generate EBIT. Exhibit 4 outlines the calculated EBIT headwind of £57 mn from
parking and lease expiries; in addition, given the decline in flight hours for Trent 800 and
Trent 500 observed in 2014 and 2015, we assume a further decline in 2016E and build this
into our forecasts, adding an extra £9 mn headwind to EBIT.

11:43 am
BE

Won't share the charts.

BE

For something that's actually readable, though, here's Sandy Morris.

BE

Jefferies, of course. House broker. Still buyer, but not ducking from the problems.

11:44 am
BE

August 2000. In August 2000, RR warned it expected 2001 earnings to be flat, having
previously guided for compound growth of 10%. One reason for the warning was the
“current mix of business in civil aerospace, where recent market success has resulted in a higher proportion of original equipment sales relative to spares sales, compounded by the removal
from service of a number of mature engines”. RR never specified the engines and the airlines, but back then we believed it was engines on Lockheed Tristar aircraft, probably operated by Delta (the largest operator of Tristars) that was replacing them with B767s.

BE

A sense of fear. Last week, RR again did not name the engine types or the airlines, but we
have noted the retirement of many Trent 800 powered Singapore Airlines B777 aircraft in
recent years. RR may have reviewed the status of similar aircraft in operation and chosen to
make more prudent assumptions about their longevity and utilisation, in our view. The scale
of the FY16 Wide-Body aftermarket profit warning - £100-150m – is, however, substantial.
Assuming the drop-through from sales to profit is high, it suggests the loss of perhaps
£200-250m of sales, equivalent to around 6% of reported FY14 Civil Aerospace Services
revenues. We note the Trent installed base at end 1H15 was 2,850 engines (and that likely
includes engines that are not active, yet we figure that 2,900 Trent engines were delivered
between 2001 and 1H15. We accept there can be a transition phase, but this time it is
wrapped in the mystery that is TotalCare. That may have turned uncertainty into fear.

BE

"The mystery that is TotalCare" .......... When your house broker phrases your main business in these terms, Mr East, you have a problem.

11:45 am
PM

Indeed

BE

Finished with engines. We believe RR’s valuation now allows for a scenario where
engine retirements and lower utilisation mean Wide-Body aftermarket profits and – more
importantly – cash flows are moribund for years. In short, the Civil aftermarket model has
to have broken down in order for Civil Aerospace to be valued at £2-4bn (we venture the
investment in the Trent XWB might now total around £3bn). We do not find that plausible,
but concede the retirements we anticipated would occur over some years, may have come
forward in time. RR has a chance to address this on 24 November. Reassuring words on long-term profits and cash flows did not work last week. More substance will be needed on 24 November, in our view. We imagine RR is painfully aware of that.

undefined
11:46 am
BE

Comments slow this morning, for understandable reasons.

BE

Weekend press not really giving us much to follow either.

BE

Request from @Soundbuy for MSCI index stuff.

11:49 am
BE

I have a load of quant previews of that, but they're all about 30 pages long.

BE

Unless you're into Latin America and China ADRs then, sorry, I'm not going to dump all that here. Perhaps usual place would be better.

BE

In the meantime, miners would be a good place to alight.

11:51 am

PM

From Europe both GLEN and VED announced dividend suspensions in Q315. Resource
dividend yields are at the very top end of the market reflecting weak prices and investor
concerns around sustainability. RIO is the only major where we have confidence that the
progressive dividend can be sustained. BHP so far remains committed to the progressive
policy but the market appears to be already pricing in a 20-30% reduction based on
relative yield. We expect Anglo to announce a reduction in the progressive dividend and
move to a pay-out policy (we model 40% payout policy from H215) later this year (Investor
Day on 8th December).

11:59 am
BE

Oh, just as a postscript on Glencore, Christopher LaFemina at Jefferies has updated his valuation maths and arrived at exactly the market price.

BE

Scenario analysis: We estimate that Glencore would generate $7.3bn of EBITDA in '16 at
current spot commodity prices. If we assume prices fall by 10%, EBITDA would be $6.2bn
($2.9bn in Marketing and $3.3bn in Industrials). If we value Marketing at 9x EBITDA (high
multiple due to low interest and taxes and low cyclicality) and Industrials at 6x EBITDA, we
value Glencore at $46bn. Subtract from that EOY 2015E net debt of $25bn, and we get an
equity value of $21bn, or 98p/sh.

BE

DX issued a tough profit warning on Friday. Trading conditions are challenging due to higher driver costs, pricing pressure in UK parcels and a more rapid decline in document volumes in the core DX Exchange business. We make deep cuts to our forecasts; at EBITDA, by over 40% to £20m for FY16 and by similar amounts for FY17 and FY18. We also cut our dividend in line with new guidance from DX (i.e. 2.5p for FY16). Our TP is cut to 26p from 115p. This statement is clearly disappointing given that FY15 results were only in late September and management sounded upbeat on the outlook. On our revised forecasts, DX is trading on a calendar 2016e PE of just 4.4x (vs. the sector on 12x) and has a twice-covered dividend yielding 10.9%. That said, our concern is that these troubles may endure. Our recommendation is cut to HOLD from BUY

BE

And Numis.

12:02 pm
BE

DX's profit warning combines a more rapid than expected decline in Document
Exchange revenues (which have a c.100% drop-through margin), significant
additional costs driven by the shortage of HG drivers who are CPC qualified, and
a slower than anticipated take-on of new parcels and freight business. We are
cutting our underlying operating profit and forecasts by c.55% for FY16-18e, and
now forecast a dividend cut of c.60% (see table 1). We reduce our recommendation
from BUY to HOLD and our price target from 110p to 33p, based on our returnsbased
implied value creation model.
● Document Exchange contraction accelerates. On IPO, management anticipated a
-6%p.a volume decline in Document Exchange revenues, owing to e-substiution and
shrinkage in the number of legal practices. In year one it was -4%, year 2 it was -8% and
in the 4m to October it has been -10%. At that trajectory it implies a revenue reduction
of c.£7m in 2016, which all falls to the profit line given the fixed cost closed network.
● Acute CPC-qualified driver skill shortages. Management has commented
previously on the challenges of finding HGV drivers who have the Driver Certificate of
Professional Competence (CPC) qualifications. This is an industry issue. DX has had
to raise salaries of its HGV drivers very significantly, and the cost of agency staff has
also risen sharply. It has also had unfilled HGV driver positions and in some cases had
to use multiple smaller vehicles (e.g transit vans) to carry loads previously transported
by HGVs, which has incurred additional vehicle rental, fuel and staff costs.
● Slower than anticipated on-boarding of new contracts. At the Prelims management
commented that it had won over £20m of annualised new contracts, the full benefit of
which would be felt in 2016. However, it had also seen contract attrition. Potential new
customers are unlikely to move now before Christmas as they don't wish to risk their
increasingly IT-centric supply chains.
● Balance sheet flexibility. At Jun-15, DX had net debt of £1.8m. Owing to the buildout
of the new national hub (planning approval expect at the end of Nov), at a cost of
c.£35m, we forecast net debt rising to c.£46m in Jun-17, which would imply 2.2x ND/
EBITDA. However, management could sale and leaseback of that facility, which would
bring down core net debt materially

BE

Lot of JE press coverage recently, much of it seemingly wide of the mark. Dismiss a few flights of fancy around Amazon and all things delivery below. JE's real challenge is accelerating innovation to construct a competitive moat around the proposition to restaurants.

Certainly a healthy debate around all things JE...And not sure whether Buttress and the JE senior management team give it a second thought, but one knows one has arrived when the Sunday Time's 'Inside the City' covers you, though admittedly not with the usual aplomb of lead journalist Danny Fortson... There perhaps appear to be three recurring debates worthy of comment below.

12:05 pm
BE

1) Delivery, a key part of the offer, it seems. Most of JEs TRs are owner operated single location outlets that in the main do delivery too. When you speak to them, and have spoken to a lot, they perceive delivery as a core part of their offer, obvious perhaps, we want our takeaway to come quickly and to arrive hot. Thus, outsourcing it to the likes of Amazon is something of a non-starter. Though difficult to find an informed industry participant that thinks Amazon, Uber et al will construct a national logistics network to sustain online takeaway delivery. Still if you need 'top brands such as Kingsmill, Birds Eye and Cathedral City', Amazon Prime Now sorts you out, one hour delivery slot, £6.99 delivery fee, minimum spend £20 and the annual fee, coming down to £59 I think...

BE

2) What of Deliveroo? I think it's a great business, more of how it fits into the emerging landscape below. William Shu, CEO, certainly impressive at NOAH last week, 'just getting started, 5,000 restaurants, 3,000 drivers'. Can I stop you there? Do JE need to respond, absolutely, I call it the "Just Dine' proposition, high end, very point solution in discrete 'high end' densely populated post codes, arguably basic market segmentation...
3) And for completeness. The channel shift hasn't happened yet, still just c. 30% orders online in the UK, more logistics offers is a good thing, keeps JE honest and accelerates the shift...we don't see it as a bear thesis.

BE

Playing in the 'on demand' online economy. Thus far, we think innovation has played out in three distinct business models...
1) Online marketplaces. A broad range of discrete business models currently exist. JE, the global leader here, focuses on the technology and delivers a 'marketplace' where takeaway restaurants and consumers congregate. Increasingly mobile form factor led, the key to competitive advantage is the innovation around delivering value to the takeaway restaurant;
2) Vertically extended logistics players. Here in the UK, Deliveroo the highest profile model, addressing a higher-end set of restaurants and fulfilling the delivery piece critically. The competitive advantage here, a high quality experience, great food, great delivery and, as above, scale in the target market; and
3) Demand drivers. Haven't seen these models emerge in the UK yet, loads in the US, we used SpoonRocket on our last West Coast marketing trip. A daily menu offer that may include pasta, curries, deserts, beverages. Food is maintained at temperature in-vehicle and generally consumers meet the vehicle on the street and get high quality, fresh, hot food in about 10 minutes....very 'on demand'!

12:06 pm
BE

Valuing high growth stocks...Could use EV/Sales, EV/FCF or PE here, but EV/EBITDA the most commonly applied metric, JE shows consensus 14/17 EBITDA CAGR c. +57%, trades on 22x 17 EBITDA, on a growth adjusted basis, the cheapest of AUTO, MONY, RMV and ZPLA.

Where now for the stock from here... We sense c.£250m FY15 revenue number, implying c.+21% consensus organic growth for FY16, conservative in the first instance, think for a moment of the impact of a UK commission rate increase....JE numbers are going up...

BE

David Reynolds is the analyst. Nice to know he's a fan of Danny Fortson.
